title: Open Source Kanban Alternatives: Self-Hosted Solutions for Privacy and Control
excerpt: Want full control over your kanban data? Explore the best open-source kanban tools you can self-host, from WeKan to Taiga and beyond.
author: Kanban AI Team
body:
# Open Source Kanban Alternatives: Self-Hosted Solutions for Privacy and Control

Open-source kanban tools give you complete control over your data and infrastructure. Whether you're concerned about privacy, compliance, or just want to avoid vendor lock-in, these self-hostable solutions are worth considering.

## 1. WeKan

**Pros:**
- Clean, Trello-like interface
- Easy to set up with Docker
- Real-time collaboration
- Card comments and attachments
- Swimlanes and custom fields
- Active development community

**Cons:**
- Requires server management
- Mobile apps are limited
- Smaller feature set than commercial tools
- Community support only

**Setup Difficulty:** ⭐⭐ (Easy with Docker)

**Best for:** Teams comfortable with Docker who want a Trello alternative.

## 2. Taiga

**Pros:**
- Full project management (not just kanban)
- Supports both kanban and scrum
- Beautiful, modern interface
- Active development
- Good for software development teams
- Strong community

**Cons:**
- More complex setup
- Steeper learning curve
- Requires more server resources
- Better for technical teams

**Setup Difficulty:** ⭐⭐⭐ (Moderate)

**Best for:** Development teams wanting comprehensive agile project management.

## 3. Restyaboard

**Pros:**
- Open source Trello alternative
- Card templates
- Activity tracking
- Multiple board views
- Good documentation
- Active development

**Cons:**
- Setup can be complex
- Smaller community
- Limited mobile support
- Some features require paid version

**Setup Difficulty:** ⭐⭐⭐ (Moderate)

**Best for:** Teams wanting a Trello clone with self-hosting.

## 4. Focalboard

**Pros:**
- Created by Mattermost team
- Modern React-based interface
- Integrates with Mattermost
- Lightweight and fast
- Good for small teams
- Simple setup

**Cons:**
- Newer project (less mature)
- Smaller feature set
- Limited integrations
- Smaller community

**Setup Difficulty:** ⭐⭐ (Easy)

**Best for:** Teams already using Mattermost or wanting a lightweight solution.

## 5. Kanboard

**Pros:**
- Minimalist design
- Lightweight and fast
- Simple PHP-based setup
- Good for small teams
- Low resource requirements
- Straightforward kanban focus

**Cons:**
- Basic feature set
- Dated interface
- Limited customization
- Smaller development community
- No mobile apps

**Setup Difficulty:** ⭐⭐ (Easy)

**Best for:** Small teams wanting a simple, no-frills kanban board.

## 6. Planka

**Pros:**
- Modern, beautiful interface
- Real-time updates
- Card attachments and comments
- Docker deployment
- Active development
- Good documentation

**Cons:**
- Newer project
- Smaller community
- Limited advanced features
- Mobile support in development

**Setup Difficulty:** ⭐⭐ (Easy with Docker)

**Best for:** Teams wanting a modern, visually appealing self-hosted option.

## Comparison Table

| Tool | Setup Difficulty | Best For | Active Development | Community Size |
|------|------------------|----------|---------------------|-----------------|
| WeKan | ⭐⭐ | General teams | ✅ Active | Medium |
| Taiga | ⭐⭐⭐ | Dev teams | ✅ Active | Large |
| Restyaboard | ⭐⭐⭐ | Trello users | ✅ Active | Small |
| Focalboard | ⭐⭐ | Mattermost users | ✅ Active | Small |
| Kanboard | ⭐⭐ | Small teams | ⚠️ Slower | Medium |
| Planka | ⭐⭐ | Modern teams | ✅ Active | Small |

## Self-Hosting Considerations

### Infrastructure Requirements
- **Server:** VPS, cloud instance, or on-premises
- **Resources:** 1-4GB RAM typically sufficient
- **Database:** Most use PostgreSQL or MySQL
- **Storage:** Depends on attachments and usage

### Maintenance
- Regular updates and security patches
- Database backups
- Server monitoring
- User management

### Costs
- Server hosting ($5-50/month typically)
- Domain name (optional)
- SSL certificate (free with Let's Encrypt)
- Your time for maintenance

## When to Choose Open Source

**Choose open source if:**
- You have data privacy/security requirements
- You need compliance (GDPR, HIPAA, etc.)
- You want to avoid vendor lock-in
- You have technical resources for hosting
- You want to customize the software
- Budget constraints favor self-hosting

**Stick with SaaS if:**
- You lack technical resources
- You want automatic updates
- You need enterprise support
- Mobile apps are critical
- You prefer not to manage infrastructure

## Our Recommendations

**For Easiest Setup:** Start with **WeKan** or **Planka** - both have straightforward Docker deployments.

**For Development Teams:** **Taiga** offers the most comprehensive features for software teams.

**For Minimalist Needs:** **Kanboard** is the simplest option if you just need basic kanban.

**For Modern Interface:** **Planka** and **Focalboard** offer the most polished user experiences.

**For Trello Users:** **WeKan** and **Restyaboard** will feel most familiar.

## Getting Started

1. **Choose your tool** based on your needs and technical comfort
2. **Set up a server** (DigitalOcean, AWS, or on-premises)
3. **Follow installation docs** (most have Docker options)
4. **Configure backups** from day one
5. **Set up SSL** for secure access
6. **Invite your team** and start using it

## Final Thoughts

Open-source kanban tools offer freedom and control, but require technical investment. If you have the resources and need the benefits, they're excellent choices. If not, consider starting with a SaaS tool and migrating later if needed.

**Remember:** The best tool is the one your team will actually use. Don't let the perfect be the enemy of the good.
